newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Rights group seeks ex-Yugoslav war crimes arrests.
newsitem.headline: Rights group seeks ex-Yugoslav war crimes arrests.

text.p: NATO leaders gathering in Madrid on Tuesday should order the arrest of those accused of war crimes in the Bosnian war or see the failure of efforts to build lasting peace in the region, rights activists said on Sunday.
"Of the 76 people from all sides publicly indicted so far, only 10 have been taken into custody," Human Rights Watch said in a statement.

Chief among those still at large are Bosnian Serb leaders Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, for whom the U.N. criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia issued international arrest warrants in July 1996 on charges of genocide and war crimes.
"NATO knows where these men are and has the legal duty and the means to apprehend them but Western political leaders refuse to order their arrest.

"Unless these men are apprehended, they will continue to undermine the peace process, prevent national reconciliation and sabotage this rare opportunity to build an international system of justice," Human Rights Watch said.
"The only force capable of making these arrests is NATO, either on its own or by providing essential back-up to a specially created commando," it added.

Heads of state and government from the 16-nation alliance are due to begin a summit on Tuesday intent on extending membership into former communist central and eastern Europe and reforming the organisation's structures.
The 35,00-strong NATO-led peace force SFOR (Stabilisation Force) is due to leave Bosnia in June 1998.
